title: 70's Estate Wagon logo—looking for similar typeface
author: aml4y4

comments.content:
None of the following are dead-on matches, but they all have a similar feel:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/argentina-lian-types/brand/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/argentina-lian-types/brand/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/argentina-lian-types/brand/")

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/sauber-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/sauber-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/typejockeys/sauber-script/")

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lacrosse/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lacrosse/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lacrosse/")

The original was most likely hand-lettered for Chevy (do I have the right maker?), by either their internal art department or the agency that helped market the vehicle.

I agree with the choice of Brand as a substitute. Lavender Script [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bluevinyl/lavender-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bluevinyl/lavender-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/bluevinyl/lavender-script/") and Shelly Script [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/shelley-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/shelley-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/shelley-script/") could also work. Balladeer Light also has a similar feel even though it is not a connected script. [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/profonts/balladeer/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/profonts/balladeer/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/profonts/balladeer/") I also like Citadel Script [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atcitadel-script/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140828221243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atcitadel-script/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/atcitadel-script/") if the hairline flourises on the capitals could be trimmed.  
Don

Don, I agree with you on Lavender Script (must have missed that one), but the other three look too "engraved" (as in cut with a burin on copper or steel) than the more pen-and-ink/brush-and-ink original.

Kevin, I was looking mainly at the letter-forms rather than the writing tool suggested in the digital font. My idea was that if someone wanted to make a replica of the word-mark emblem writing tool details could be blurred out for use in the 3-D printing process. I agree that they would not work properly if used "as is."  
Don
